Fields.DialogueText: All hands to battlestations!
@BATTLE
What's your status, Wicher?
... Zadowalajacy. Everything's good to go.
Okay, so far so good. As long as things keep going well...
Kapitan, I see another line of ships coming in from the portside.
Shoot – reinforcements. We're going to need to fall back.
But that's not part of the plan. We need to continue with our raid.
Wicher, that plan only accounted for the initial forces. We have to change things around now.
Nevertheless, we should still follow our orders, to the letter.
That could get us killed.
So could abandoning the plan now that we're in the thick of it.

Fields.MenuText: You sure like to have things orderly, don't you?
I'm just worried that we won't be able to fulfill our objectives now if we don't change anything.
Well, my orders are that the orders for the plan are to change.

Fields.DialogueText: But of course. Harmony must triumph over chaos. If we let the rules slide, who knows where we'll end up?
Whoever said we couldn't change things around?
Very well, I understand. But be careful about changing your beat too much. Decisiveness is the key to victory.
Okay, sometime we can clarify the difference between "objectives" and "plan." But it won't make a difference if we sink.
Don't worry, Kapitan. We have to keep our faith in the orders, and in our ability to make them work.
That's one way to look at it. In that case, let's get on with it!
@BATTLE
But you said...?
I said that the orders and the plan cannot be altered. But we may have to find a new approach to how we carry out the plan to ensure that it still works.
Wicher? You've been in here half the day - what are you... okay, that smells mighty good.
Oh, Kapitan! I was just finishing up some nice kielbasa.
Consider me impressed.
Dziekuje bardzo! I make a fine sausage when I get the inclination.
There sure is a lot of it, though. Planning to share it with everyone in the fleet?
That's exactly it. One of my Polish sisters made a formal request of it. And, you know, some of the girls have hungry appetites.
That makes sense. Still, this is a bit much.
We can't have our sailors getting thin on us! Out here, you never know how long until you can get a good meal.

Fields.MenuText: Just as long as you don't drain our food stocks too much, things should be fine.
What will we do with the remaining food?
This was nice of you.

Fields.DialogueText: We should be okay - I took careful note of how much we should need in the following days.
We can preserve most of it for the time being, and the rest we can use for bait to restock with fish.
I just want to do what I can to help out around the fleet.
Mind if I have a bit, please?
Go right ahead. There's plenty for everybody.
Mmm, delicious! You are a master chef.
You're overstating things. But as far as kielbasa is concerned - tak, I know what I'm doing.
Anyway. It looks like everybody is arriving for the picnic.
And some uninvited guests as well. Come on – they won't hurt anyone here on my watch!
@BATTLE
Well, I can't argue with that. You're always on top of things.
Okay. Now, if we said the *objective* was to get a huge amount of kielbasa made, and the *plan* was to use this galley - but there was a fire and another galley was available...
Why would there be a fire? I'm very careful.
... I'm pretty sure you're joking, but I don't want to presume.
Tak. I am. But you have to understand, I represent a nation that's on the very edge of... of ceasing to exist. I need to prove I can do what needs to be done in the way it needs to be done.
Yeah, well - you don't have to prove it to me, Wicher.
How are you today, Wicher?
Bardzo dobrze dziekuje. I've read our new orders, and we're about ready to go. I'm just sorting out some of our munitions.
That's good. Better to do it now than have to scramble when Morganas come calling.
*ALARM*
And speak of the devil, here's some now. Coming, Wicher? Uh, Wicher?
Just a second, Kapitan. I need to finish organizing the equipment down here.
Look, secure anything that needs to be secured, but the basic inventory work can wait. We-
If I suddenly shift gears now, everything would be disorganized later! I can get it done!
Wicher.
I don't want to mess anything up!

Fields.MenuText: You have a sharp mind. I'm confident you'll remember where you left off.
Is it that important right now?
You can be kind of slow, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: A valid point. I guess I could leave it be for now – assuming nobody tampers with it until I come back.
I consider keeping every part of me at its strongest potential for battle, and I do not intend to get sloppy with it.
I prefer the term methodical. An organized hold will be essential in battle.
You know, Kapitan, you should watch your blood pressure. You seem nervous.
All right, I'm finished with that. If only I hadn't had to rush things...
Good. Now can we get on with the battle?
Jestem w drodze! Don't worry – with everything fixed up inside me, this battle will be a cinch.
@BATTLE
Yes, but we're in one now.
Hey, what are you doing out here?
Oh. No, thank you, it's okay. I enjoy the wind on my face - the gale that gave me my name.
So you're immune to the weather? I mean, in the sense of not needing extra clothes or anything?
Well, I am a little chilly, but I'm... well, I'm finding a bit of comfort out here.
Comfort? Is something troubling you?
Nothing in particular. I just feel a little uneasy, all the way out here.
We're not isolated from everything – there's plenty of resources here with the fleet, and we can still find land readily enough.
Tak. But we're a long way from Poland.
Ah, that's what it is. You're homesick.
Kind of. But that's something for another time.

Fields.MenuText: The wind travels all across the world, back and forth, but it's always bound to reach home once more in the end.
Well, we all have things we miss out on out here. But we have a job to do.
You know, if you weren't out here, you wouldn't be feeling that breeze. So there's always a bright side to things depending on how you look at it.

Fields.DialogueText: An interesting strand of thought. You have the makings of a philosopher.
Masz racje. In the end, it all comes down to duty. I just hope that my efforts will help Poland.
Good point. I guess that wherever you go, there are ups and downs.
Anyway, if you ever want to talk about things, just know that I'm here.
Thanks, but I'll be fine. I want to be able to support everyone, and I can't let them down by getting depressed. Besides, there's usually enough going on to keep me occupied.
And, in the meantime, the Morganas' waves never seem to end.
@BATTLE
Don't worry! I'm not shirking! I have a few minutes in my schedule before I'm expected to-
I'm not accusing you of anything, Wicher - it's just that the wind is pretty rough. Wouldn't you rather be inside?
Even if our convoy protection duties seem somewhat wasted without a convoy to protect.
There'll be a rendezvous at some point.
Hello, Wicher.
Wicher?
...Yawn! Hmm? Oh, Dzien dobry, Kapitan.
Why so sluggish? You're always a little slow, but you seem so tired right now.
Oh, I was just up all night, keeping watch.
You took a round-the-clock shift? Wicher, we have multiple watches so people don't have to do that.
Yes, but I wanted everyone to get a good rest, so I said I'd cover for them.
And so not everyone got sleep in the end.
I'll be fine. Zzzz... What were we saying?

Fields.MenuText: Wicher, the rules about shifts exist for a reason. I'd expect you to be all for obeying them.
We all need time to take it easy, even you. We can handle some of the burdens as well.
You need to get enough sleep if you want to stay alert and protect everybody.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. I can't just go breaking them all of a sudden. I will make sure to keep with the schedule in the future.
Thanks. It's just...I want to be able to look after everyone and alleviate at least a bit of what they have to suffer.
I suppose you have a point. I hate it when I miss things, and it's tough when I doze off.
I'll make sure I get enough shut-eye. Or at least I'll keep trying.
Yeah, shopping when you're sleep-deprived always makes things better.
*ALARM*
...  Morganas? Here I come!
Wicher, are you awake enough for this battle?
Sure, why not?
Well, you were about to walk into that bulkhead instead of onto the deck.
Oh. Well, the battle's snapped me awake, so I won't let things slip by me anymore.
@BATTLE
Ah. Insomnia problems?
I wouldn't call it a *problem*. But, tak. It didn't seem like much of a sacrifice to offer to keep watch if it was going to be up all night thinking too loud anyway.

Fields.MenuText: I've been there.
Anything I can do to help?
Is it worth talking to the doctor? Or an engineer?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sorry to hear that.
Oh, I'm fine!
But, don't worry - I'm fine.
Actually, I've ordered a few things that should help my state of mind. I really will be okay.
Zzzzzz.
*sigh*
What's the matter, Wicher? You seem upset about something.
Nie, nie! I just need to clear the air a bit.
How can you "clear the air" if you won't tell – is that a fan you're turning on?
Right. Here it goes.
Wicher! You have the fan on too high! It's blowing everything away.
Good. Maybe that will clear away some of the smoke.
Smoke? Were some of the boys lighting cigars on the bridge again?
Tak, so I took necessary measures. It's for their own good.
Well, I know some people say they're bad for your health, but still...
Not that. I'm talking about the smoke billowing all over the place.
What's wrong with that?
What's wrong?! It's a hazard, that's what's wrong! We need to stay on guard for the next assault, and if we keep having smog hazing around, who knows what might happen?

Fields.MenuText: Wicher, calm down. You shouldn't get so worked up.
INPF regulations permit smoking, Wicher, and not a single member state objected. It's their choice.
I don't see you making a fuss when you're cooking.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. I still dislike it, but I should uphold my honor as a soldier and not cause such a mess.
But suppose their choice endangers us all? Then something must be done.
That's different – the activity, in that case, is at least necessary for survival. And besides, I always make sure to keep things clean in the kitchen.
... Perhaps I got a little carried away.
Uh-huh. Well, you certainly got rid of it.
Or perhaps not. I can smell another strand of it out to sea.
Out to sea? Then that smoke is coming from someone – or something – else entirely!
Morganas, always making a lot of trouble. Time for us to clean things up and blow them away.
@BATTLE
Wicher... are you okay? Between this and the sleep deprivation event the other day, you seem to be-
I don't know. A bit on-edge.
Oh, I'm fine. You know, I just really don't like smoke.
You haven't been awake for forty-eight hours or anything, have you?
*ALARM*
All hands on deck, all hands on...!
Oof! Oh no! Ah!
Are you all right, Wicher? I didn't mean to bump into you like that.
Jestem w porzadku! I'm fine! I'm just glad nothing got hurt.
I wouldn't say that. Why didn't you use your hands to break your fall?
Because I was making sure that nothing got hurt. See, they're all okay.
Oh, you were protecting those books.
Yes. I was moving them to my quarters when the alarm started, and I want to get them to safety before they are damaged.

Fields.MenuText: If you're worried about them getting damaged, shouldn't you use more than a small piece of lace to tie them together?
Focus on looking after yourself first. Books can come and go, but people are another story.
Hurry and put them away somewhere, anywhere. If the Morganas sink us, it won't matter where you have them stored.

Fields.DialogueText: They were just shipped in from Warsaw. Besides, it gives the set a delicate touch, does it not?
I guess that you're right, in the end, lives trump books. Still, books represent the legacies of minds, so I wish to protect them as well.
Okay, okay. I'll be back in a moment.
I guess I'll wait here, then...
Waiting...
Morganas approaching...
They're secured, Kapitan.
Good. Now we can get on with things.
My thoughts exactly.
Say, what books were they, out of curiosity?
We can talk about that when we have time later, Kapitan. What are you waiting for? We have a job to do!
So now I'm the late one?
@BATTLE
Wicher...
Just give me a moment!
Kapitan? You're just in time.
Morganas, huh? I just came up to the bridge for the coffee.
Really?
No. Be ready - they're almost in range.
@BATTLE
There! That should teach them a lesson!
I doubt it. Those creeps never seem to learn. Still, this calls for a celebration. Care for a toast?
I probably shouldn't while I'm on duty. On the bridge.
Chartreuse liquor, straight from France. Its taste has an aged depth to it, befitting its origin.
You're a big fan of the French, then?
Well, I respect their culture – they've given rise to many thinkers of their own. But I can't say I'm the happiest at present with them.
Ah. I take it that's because-
It's nothing. Anyway, the toast! What should we toast to?

Fields.MenuText: Victory.
Our homelands.
Peace.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed, that is what we have to be merry for today. To our victory, now and always!
Yes... to our homelands. May we live to see them once more, and may they live to see us again.
An excellent idea. To peace. May we all find respite in these dark hours.
You look like you're enjoying it.
I choose only the best. But there's plenty more - you're sure I can't tempt you?
No, thanks - this will be more than sufficient.
That's all right. I'll see if some of the others want a sip themselves. This is a victory to be shared amongst all - with your permission?
Sure. As long as all the fires are out.
But if you're done for the day, I don't mind if you take a sip. What is it, by the way? It looks kind of fancy. Another one of your new acquisitions?
Here, let me get you some water - we can still have that toast.
Oh. Thank you.
They never are. We have to make our own moments all the same, I think.
What are you working on in here?
Just making some traditional craftworks.
Oh, I see. Some sort of paper art?
Yes, wycinanki. It's an old art form back in Poland and other lands to the east.
Interesting. Mind if I give it a try?
Oczywiscie! Let me just... ah. Here are some extra scissors.
Okay, let's see what I can do.
*snip*
*snip snip snip snip snip*
Well, I think I'm about finished.
Same here. Why don't we compare them?
Good idea. So, what do you think?

Fields.MenuText: I did a rough job, didn't I?
Yours is amazing.
I had a lot of fun.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be so hard on yourself. The tradition started out with carving straight out of trees, so you can afford to be a little wild with your work.
Thank you, but you did well as well. I like how you brought your own ideas into the mix.
That's the best part, isn't it? In the end, it is simply the act of engaging in art like this that gives you self-fulfillment.
I have to say, this is pretty interesting. Where should we put them?
I have a spot for mine right over there. But you can keep yours, Kapitan.
Thanks. Now I just need to find a place for mine before – oh, come on! Now?
Nie martw sie. These Morganas may have a lot of bark, but they'll shred like paper in our wind.
@BATTLE
Have you been sleeping any better?
Are you here to check up on me, then?
No, I'm here to cut up little pieces of paper. I'm just checking up on you to pass the time.
Ha! Tak. I am sleeping better. Thank you.
*snip snip*
It's good to have all these distractions, I think.
It's not so bad when I have things to do. Or when there are clear orders to follow!
But when we're just waiting...
Ugh. It's awful.
*snip*
Okay, Wicher, I have the information for our next mission.
Wporzo. What is the plan?
Obviously, merchant traffic has been light lately; Morganas have a de facto blockade going on nearer the American coasts.
That's... interesting. Who?
Turns out that there's a Kriegsmarine group in the area, and they've agreed to help out. It's actually kind of a diplomatic coup, since the British Merchant Navy will benefit as much as anyone.
I know you hate it. But take a deep breath.
... Well, it is good that they say they will help. But I would have rather had it been someone else. The Germans on my crew I trust, but people reporting to Berlin?
I understand. I really do. But they're sailing under the flag of the INPF, and there's a decent chance that thirty or forty percent of their crew is from other nations.
But the Nazis will still be able to release propaganda about "helping us."
And that's assuming they don't try to insist you bring more Nazi officers aboard.
Such a poisonous group, with the manners of a cuckoo. I would never trust them with my back.

Fields.MenuText: Still, we'll need to cooperate to finish the mission. Can you still work with them?
Why do you seem so uneasy? We can take them if they try to pull something funny.
Hey, we're all in this war against the Morganas together, right?

Fields.DialogueText: I won't be happy about it, but I'll deal with it.
Out here, maybe, but back home? Who knows what they could try. Or already have.
Out here, maybe, but what about on land? And even the peace out here may not last beyond our victory.
We're to the mobilizing point. Uh, oh – it looks like the Morganas already found our allies.
Hurry! We need to save them!
I thought you didn't like them?
No, but if there are any innocents on board, I would never forgive myself if I allowed them to perish.
That's... very noble of you, Wicher. Okay, move forward, everyone! It's not over yet!
@BATTLE
Command is organizing a push to clear the shipping lanes. We'll be doing our bit on the European side - and for the time being we'll have a little backup.
Enemy's almost in range, Wicher.
Niech przyjda! We're ready for them, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Take that! Did I get them, Kapitan?
By and large, yes. But the targeting seemed kind of erratic. That last salvo...
Sorry about that. The wind swept my hair into my face.
Look, can't you cut it or something? It's always getting tangled like this.
But I like my hair this way.
Okay, then stay on the bridge and out of the wind during battle so we don't have this trouble.
But it's good to be able to respond to problems on the deck as they happen - you know it is!
Oh, brother...
I'm sorry, Kapitan. I know that I'm not the best soldier. But I still try to do my best.

Fields.MenuText: Still, if this keeps making you fumble, you'll need to do something.
What if you used something to secure your hair during fights? Like the hair net you use when cooking.
I understand. I won't stop you from enjoying the things you love.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, but please give me another chance.
Not a bad idea. That could work. Thanks for the suggestion.
Thank you. I would have cut it if ordered, but I'm glad you're willing to let me keep it long.
Anyway, I was more concerned for you, since it's giving you trouble.
Thanks, but I'll be okay. The length of my hair is just a little thing, and the happiness I feel when I see it more than makes up for it.
Well, we still have some known hostiles in the area. If all the fires here are put out, we resume our patrols.
Don't worry. I'm very good at putting out fires.
Fine. Maybe I was a little too harsh.
... And I like the gales as well.
... Yeah. Yeah, there's something to be said for hanging on to the little things.
So. Should I ask how things went during our rendezvous with our friends from the Kriegsmarine?
The Belles were relatively civilized. We have a common enemy, after all.
Good.
One of the human commanders told me I was a traitor to the "true" government of Poland. That was fun.
... Thanks for not throwing him overboard. Would've been politically awkward.
Anyway. I can see now! What's next?
Hello, Wicher. Having trouble sleeping again?
A sketch of the stars.
I see. Is it for navigational purposes or just an artist's fancy?
Whoever said that they have to be separate in that way?
Pardon?
The earliest arts stemmed from our wonder at the mysteries around us, and our attempts to grasp the truth. Therefore, science, philosophy, and art are one and the same.
That's a pretty interesting perspective on things.
Gaze out into the cosmos – whether it is "day" or "night" here. There is endless mystery and chaos that shifts depending on our current vision. How is that not art?

Fields.MenuText: It all sounds kind of complicated.
I suppose that discovering new things has its own kind of beauty.
The universe is such a vast place, isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: That's what makes things interesting. There are so many different interpretations to explore.
Yes, learning is always a wonderful adventure.
Yes, but every little thing still has its own value. Which is why we must never lose hope. Our efforts, no matter how small, will surely make a ripple in time.
You're an interesting person, Wicher. Very complex.
I do my best.
And you *are* okay? Sleepless night notwithstanding?
Funny you should ask.
*ALARM*
If only we could have a perfect chart on the Morganas – then things would be smooth sailing for once.
@BATTLE
Oh, it's not so bad.
As long as you don't start walking into bulkheads again.
I *can* pass through them.
Were you going to last time?
Hm. You ask the most awkward questions.
Sorry. What are you working on there?
Dzien dobry, Kapitan!
Good day to you, too, Wicher. I see that you're planting some seeds in that pot. Planning to grow some flowers?
Just a few at the moment - but I think that they'll help to lighten up the atmosphere out here.
Yes, flowers have a way of cheering us up. Though you will need to be careful with them. It's rather difficult for most plants to thrive out here.
I know, but it's a way to make me feel at home.
In that case, why didn't you start with more? Better chance of more surviving longer, after all.
Tak - but I do not want to see these little seeds as expendable, mattering only in their quantity. I want each of them to grow to be nice and healthy, with quality care and love.

Fields.MenuText: You certainly have a love for all things.
That's right. Quality is just as important as quantity.
Still, if things work out, you can grow more later.

Fields.DialogueText: I do. I have explored many philosophies, but at the core, I believe that everything deserves to exist in this world, and be loved.
Exactly. I want to be sure that I can give all of them the necessary attention they need.
Good point. Perhaps in time we can start a garden, if the first set works out all right.
Looks like they're all planted and ready to go. How long will it take for them to sprout?
Two or three weeks, I think - though some of the other Belles say they've had some luck making things grow faster.
I'm interested to see what they'll look like once they're full grown.
I just hope I can protect them... everyone.
Let's assume it's possible and work from there.
Hm.
So. Gardening. What's next?
An interruption, I'm afraid.
Oh. Time to plant some daisies on the Morganas again?
@BATTLE
Tak. You know me and sleepless nights - I try to make them productive.
By buying things.
Poppy seeds aren't that expensive, you know. Even in wartime.
Oh, I wasn't complaining. How many are we talking about here?
Isn't that a nice thought? That just by being who were are we can bring life along?
But, if not, I can be patient. All things come in time. Right?
Relatively tall. Very red. They're lovely.
Word is we've got another merchant convoy heading our way, for what it's worth. Our German colleagues will be rendezvousing, and then escorting them until we can take the baton.
Unless a U-boat sinks them and they blame it on the Morganas. You said British Merchant Navy, right?
Yeah. Listen, I'm not asking you to trust Berlin - but if we're talking about commanders of Belles, we have to have faith that they'll serve faithfully. Otherwise we're already lost.
... I'll try.
Talk to me if you're having trouble with it. Seriously.
Ouch!
Are you okay, Wicher?
I'm fine. I just poked myself with the needle.
Just try to be more careful. That's an interesting flag you're sewing up.
Dziekuje. It is of my birthplace in Caen.
Excellent. What's the tower supposed to represent?
... Long ago, there was an invasion, and the town was sacked. But the local castle held out.
Hence the single tower. That makes sense. And the INPF would certainly approve of commemorating a site in France.
Yes, but it's not just about the place. The feelings this flag evokes of being a sanctuary in times of destruction... they're a comfort out here.

Fields.MenuText: Well, we have plenty of floating castles out here, so we're bound to hold out for a long time.
Don't get too depressed. Things will get better.
In any case, you did a great job patching up the flag.

Fields.DialogueText: Good point. With all of us working together, we can stand up against the darkness. But we'll need to take action on our own if we want to help everyone else.
Not the best at giving pick-me-ups, are you? Still, thanks.
Thank you. I wanted to make it nice and neat, so that it can continue to serve as a symbol of courage.
You know, this is an interesting flag, and I like how you've sewn it. I wouldn't mind seeing one of your flags for Poland another time.
I have some of those as well. I'm doing my best to protect them. They're one of my last links to my homeland.
Well, bring them out sometime. I know we'll get a few complaints, but they'd be good for the morale of our Polish crew.
Tak - you're right. Say, Kapitan?
Yes?
I know it doesn't belong on the ship, but could we perhaps make a miniature battlement?
Like the one in the picture? Sure, it would be a nice accompaniment to the flag. Though it won't be much of a defense against these Morganas.
That's where we come in. As long as we stand strong, this final sanctum will not be transgressed!
@BATTLE
Would this be a good time to ask just how many projects you have going on at any one time? Just out of curiosity.
It's... perhaps more that I jump from one to the next. I mean, I finish them! But-
But I guess it's not really in a gale's nature to stay in one place indefinitely.
Tak! Exactly!
*ALARM*
Though there are certainly problems I keep coming back to.
Hmm...
Something bothering you, Wicher?
Just looking through the mail from home.
I take it from your expression that the news is more bad than good.
Nie, there's *no* bad news! That's exactly what worries me.
I assume you're not just being paradoxical for the sake of mental stimulation.
Nie. We know that things are not all right back there. We were already in a tense situation before I left, and I cannot see things having gotten better at this point.
The official briefings the INPF issues are... vague about the land war. But the Nazis' side certainly seems to be getting more and more dug in.
That's why I wanted the letter to say more. I hate being in the position of not knowing what's going on.

Fields.MenuText: Well, they say that no news is good news.
Perhaps they simply do not wish to trouble you with the extra burden out here.
What if you worked to communicate more with them as well? It's a two-way street, after all.

Fields.DialogueText: That is what some people say, but I would rather have the truth than an illusion, even if it hurt.
If that is what they think, then they do not know me at all. I love my country with all my heart, and their woes are my own.
I see. If I kept stronger ties with my home ports, they might, in turn, reciprocate the favor. Thanks for the advice.
In any case, I just wish I knew what was happening back at home, good or bad.
You must be really worried.
With so many of us gone from home, who's left to defend Poland?
Hey. We're *still* defending Poland.
I know. I know! Even if I cannot be there to protect my nation from human madness, I can at least ensure that other threats never reach its harbors.
Right. These Morganas are going down.
@BATTLE
They're winning. Maybe they think they've already won. The people who claim *I'm* the traitor...
Dzien dobry, Kapitan.
Hello, Wicher. More sketches, I see.
Yes, but these are from a while back.
Got it. A lizard... did you see the real thing yourself?
Tak - while I was stationed at Madeira in the Atlantic. A few found their way aboard.
Well, you did a really good job in capturing its physical details and its vitality. It almost looks like it could jump off the page.
Dziekuje! I wanted to record the archipelago's unique features for posterity.
I take it you have happy memories of Madeira overall.
Tak. I do. Islands are so interesting, having their unique cultures and stories. It's too bad they're so easily threatened. Such a shame.

Fields.MenuText: Well, we are entering an age where no place is truly an island anymore, for better or worse.
Opening up to new things can be good, right?
It just means that we have to work hard to protect as much as we can.

Fields.DialogueText: I know. In some ways, I look forward to the exchange of ideas. On the other hand, what will be lost as well?
It can, but it also exposes the islands – and countries – to threats that can overwhelm them.
Exactly. Even the smallest things have their own value, so I want to help ensure that they can all continue to thrive as unique, precious parts of this planet.
You know, we might well make our way back to Madeira one of these days. You could give me a dockside tour.
Or I could send *you* ashore with a camera and a dozen rolls of film.
I've done worse things on shore leave. We need to keep up the work out here first, though. Our latest convoy has to be getting closer, and the Morganas aren't exactly fading away.
There are some of the floating trash islands over there! Time to clean up these waters and get rid of these invasive species.
@BATTLE
I thought I might do the same with little parts of Poland. Draw pictures of home. But it's... I think it's beyond me today.
Not in the mood?
Not in the mood. So I just look at old sketches of happy little lizards.
What's the matter, Wicher? I know you're not a big fan of hearing German over radio, but the news isn't bad.
Look down, and you'll see.
Oh, I do see. You're upset about these ashes again.
Yeah. Tak, tak, tak.
I'm sorry about that. I'll tell everyone to call off the barbecues.
It's okay, it's just who I am.
What do you dislike so much about smoke and ash, anyway?
Besides it reducing visibility and causing respiratory issues? Because it makes me think of death.
Death?
Tak. In the olden days, men would have their remains converted to ashes and sealed in urns.
And the smoke reminds you of that?
Exactly. It's not a very logical fear, I admit. Sorry that I'm making a fuss about it.

Fields.MenuText: We all have our own philosophies on life and death. It's perfectly fine for you to have your own view.
But you're right – smoke can be hazardous, so we need to be careful.
Just know that, with all of us here, you shouldn't need to worry about death for a long time.

Fields.DialogueText: Thanks for accepting me for who I am.
I'm glad you see it my way, Kapitan. I have my own prejudices, but most of all I want to make sure that everyone can be safe.
Thanks, Kapitan. You're the best.
Just remember that ashes can symbolize a lot of things – snow, fire, life...
Morganas approaching.
Yes,  Morganas, too, but that's getting back on the negative side... wait, what do you mean, Morganas approaching?
Just like I said. Over there.
Ah. That reminds me of one more positive connotations for smoke - when the thing on fire is the enemy. Blast them to bits!
@BATTLE
Hey, we have to all learn to live together out here. What are friends for?
Nie, it's not that.
The convoy has escaped U-boats and Morganas alike, from the sound of it. It's-
Then what?
*ALARM*
Dammit. We didn't get much warning this time.
Well, warned or not, we'll make do.
@BATTLE
Kapitan! The last of the fires are out, and I've personally delivered our injured crew members to the doctor's care.
Great! Keep up the good work. We're making good headway here, so we just need to...
Wait, over there! Look!
Ha! I think that's our long-awaited convoy! The German escort must be guarding their backsides.
Whatever the Germans are doing, there are still Morganas out here. If the convoy gets caught in the next wave, they'll all be sunk.
Well said. Even if it sounded a bit painful.
I don't know if those particular German sailors participated in the attack on Westerplatte, but... in *this* war, we're allies.

Fields.MenuText: Good. Then our current plan involves ensuring the survival of every human being within a few hundred miles. Agreed?
If it's of any comfort, I think some of them would be really annoyed to hear you say that.
I know. It's one of the things I admire about you.

Fields.DialogueText: I like it, Kapitan. The best plans are the ones you could encapsulate on the back of a postcard.
Heh. Thank you, Kapitan.
That and my guns.
I have to say, you've grown a lot, Wicher.
I appreciate the compliment. Now, though - when something needs to be done, best to do it rather than hesitate and lose the chance.
Well said. Let's get alongside that convoy and get them where they need to be - and heaven help any Morganas that show up along the way.
Our German friends-
Ugh.
Our German friends are supposed to have a battle group of some kind locked down to the west. I guess these are reinforcements.
... And there's a risk of our INPF allies being flanked as well. I won't have that.
I couldn't forgive myself if I were less worthy of their trust than they are of yours.
It's a very compelling package deal.
Hello, Wicher. I see that you're fishing.
Nie, but the day is still young. I've only been out here for a few hours, after all.
Only a few hours, she says. I have to say, you must have the patience of a saint to wait that long.
Oh, it's not that much trouble for me. I enjoy this sort of activity.
But don't you get bored?
Bored? Never. This is an opportunity to let my mind drift and contemplate life – while staying alert for the slightest tug, of course.
Huh. I guess anything can be interesting depending on how you look at it.
Dokladnie tak. "Boredom" comes from people not paying attention to life's beauty.

Fields.MenuText: Still, is it kind of grating when you don't have much luck at catching anything?
Plus, you're the kind of person who keeps at it once you get started, right?
Well, when you're finished, think you can cook it up into a good sausage?

Fields.DialogueText: A little, but it helps me learn to cope with failure. Win or lose out here, I can still try my hardest.
Gee, you know me pretty well, Kapitan. And you're right – who knows? A few minutes in the future, there might be a bite if I just keep to the plan.
Sure. You know I'm always ready to make a good sausage.
Wicher, you might want to call off your fishing trip for the moment.
Why? I see some ripples, so I may have some better luck soon.
The ripples are exactly it. There are Morganas past the fog.
I see. Can't be helped. I'll just reel in my line, and then we'll be ready to fight.
At the rate you're going, you're better off just tying it up for the moment. Not like any fish are going to stay around at this point.
@BATTLE
We're not going anywhere while the convoy sorts out its mechanical issues, so... why not?
Sheer frustration? I mean, have you gotten any bites so far?
Wicher, what are you doing? The whole galley is flooded with meat! I can't even get inside!
Of course you can't! How else could I make the mess hall into a kielbasa?
I know that you like making kielbasa, and I know you want to show hospitality to our convoy friends, but this is too much. That's got to be thousands of-
Actually, this is just one sausage.
One sausage?! How is this one sausage? And why would you make one large enough to fill the mess hall?
No, no, silly. I'm going to make the cafeteria into a kielbasa.
... Okay? And...?
Kapitan, I don't think you grasped my meaning.
Wait... you mean...?
Yes, this is just the filling – and the room itself will constitute the casing.

Fields.MenuText: This... is a little extreme.
Where will we eat, though?
I have to say, this is quite the unique recipe.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, don't be such a worrywart.
Out on the deck. There's plenty of space out there, and you can feel the wind against your neck.
Thanks. I'm proud that I pulled it off. It'll be great when it's finished.
And the best part is that current weather conditions will let us store the food for a while – and cook it all back up when we need to.
That's good, because we need to deal with an enemy patrol right now.
I understand. Say, want to see me make a kielbasa out of Morganas?
Just as long as I don't have to eat it.
@BATTLE
... I thought that was what was happening. Damn it, why didn't you tell me until now?
What's wrong, Wicher?
I just got more news from home. This time... well, it's not good.
I see. Do you want... to go back?
Nie, I would be abandoning all of you out here, and I swore an oath. But, darn it, why did they let this happen?!
Which part of it?
Sending me away! To where I have to agonize over helping Nazis! There were only a few of us – enough to count on one hand – defending the harbors.

Fields.MenuText: At least you know what's happening now. At least they told you.
It must hurt a lot. But if you need anything, we're here for you.
The Kriegsmarine isn't actively involved in the land war now, though. You really are where your people need you.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, but only because it's too late for me to do anything. This is why I hate it when people tell white lies.
Thank you... you're very good to me, Kapitan.
Is that true, though? Would my people really be no better off if I were just keeping the Morganas out of Gdansk Bay?
Don't give up hope. We have to keep faith in our homelands, that they can find the strength to hold on just like us, out here.
Tak. I know you're right. We're not the strongest or biggest nation, but we've survived blow after blow. Those Germans and Russians will regret crossing us.
And there are a few others who will be feeling regrets a bit sooner, I think.
Good idea. Honestly, I could use the opportunity to burn off some steam.
@BATTLE
So why did they send me away? They need me right now, more than ever!
Is the alarm about to go off?
Tak.
Okay, I'll meet you on the bridge.
Oof! Hey, Kapitan, do you think you could give me a hand, please?
... To celebrate getting our convoy safely to port, you've upped your gardening from flowers to trees? Really?
Okay. So, the pussy willow is a special tree back home, and I think it will be good luck out here.
Oof. Right. Special in what way?
For one, it is said to protect against lightning strikes, and it has some spiritual symbolism as well.
In any case, what do you think of the tree?

Fields.MenuText: I'm not exactly sure if a tree would repel lightning – kind of the opposite, actually.
The branches look fairly sturdy.
At least now you'll have an extra source for your paper cutting.

Fields.DialogueText: I kind of doubt it either, but it's the thought that counts.
Yes, enough for a rudimentary weapon – or just knocking someone on the head for fun.
Maybe. I don't want to hurt it, after all.
Thanks for helping me out, Kapitan.
No problem. How on earth are we going to keep it from tipping over in a storm? It's in a big pot-thing, but still.
I have some ideas. And the effort is worth it if it helps me remember the place I'll return to someday.
Just be careful that it doesn't get in the crossfire from our fights – and it looks like another one's about to start.
@BATTLE
Here's hoping Blyskawica doesn't take it personally.
Oh, she won't. Actually, maybe I should get her one too, just as a joke.
Hang on, let me get a grip on this thing...
Got it?
Yeah.
Great. Where are we-
Just a few more steps... here!
Aaa! No!
What happened, Wicher? I heard a loud crash.
I just dropped a few pottery pieces I was working on. Don't worry - I'll get them picked up.
The hobby of the day is pottery? Interesting.
Anyway. This is a tradition of the Kashubians back home, so I thought I would try to make some of my own.
Such a shame that they broke - the pieces look nice.
Thanks, but perhaps this is a sign I should give up on this. I'll probably make another mistake.

Fields.MenuText: You just have to keep at it.
I can see that it's important to you, so don't give up on it.
Bad luck happens to all of us. You'll do better on the next try.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. I was starting to get the hang of it.
Yes, I don't want the traditions to die. Even if I am but an amateur, I will do my best to keep the art alive.
Thanks. I'll give it another go.
Okay, I'll try again.
That's great. I can't wait to see the final product.
But, first, I had best pick up the shards before someone gets hurt.
Good idea. Wait, are those Morganas over there?
You tell me. I'm kind of busy right now.
Sometimes I think you have trouble getting your priorities straight.
One thing at a time, that's my motto.
Well, once you're finished, get to your station, or we'll be the ones to be broken.
@BATTLE
You don't need to emphasize the "of the day," you know.

Fields.MenuText: Sorry. Not my intent.
Well... I mean, you do have a lot of interests. And you don't necessarily focus on any one of them too long.
The lady doth protest too much.

Fields.DialogueText: Apology accepted.
And what's wrong with that?
Nothing!
Pff.
*sigh*
Wicher, you ready? We're going to meet up with the British and French contingents for the next big raid.
Coming... let's see what they have to say.
@BATTLE
... You're not enthusiastic.
I don't know if you remember. Not long after you took command we had a talk about... I think it was plans.
And kielbasa. I remember.
And I said I represented Poland, and I needed to show that I could pull my weight. I would do things exactly the way my allies wanted them done, flawlessly.
And you have.
Tak! I have! I've worked with Germans, I've worked with Soviets, I've sailed halfway around the Atlantic! And what have they done for me in return? For Poland?
... Wicher, I'm a Neutrality Fleet captain. In a lot of ways I'm the prototype Neutrality Fleet captain. I can't have public opinions about what's going on in Europe, or Asia, and do my job.
I can only say that wars are fought at their own speed, however much we might wish otherwise.
I know.
And I don't blame you for being frustrated. Or for installing willow trees on the deck, or for turning the mess into a giant kielbasa.
You've done amazing work in impossible conditions, and I'm sorry it's had to be this way.
Nobody could do more to make sure Poland isn't forgotten, for what it's worth. Nobody.
You really didn't mind turning the mess into a giant kielbasa?

Fields.MenuText: No. But only because it tasted amazing.
No, I minded. That was a bald-faced lie.
I wasn't the one who had to clean up afterward.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh.
For what it's worth, I think you might do well to start a new project. You know as well as I do that this life of ours is easier when we're not just... left alone in our own heads.
And you think that will make me happier with the English and the French?
Or perhaps it's just that you want more willows on the deck.
I really was thinking more in terms of paper crafts. I mean, I've got a *lot* of forms I wouldn't mind you taking scissors to...
Another time, maybe. We have a different distraction at hand right now.
Say, Kapitan? I've been thinking about things.
Like what, Wicher?
On the nights when I don't sleep, I have been wondering what my purpose is out here, away from my home. I'm not as strong as the others, or as fast.
You don't have to be the strongest or the fastest.

Nie. But I mean to take up bigger projects. The other day, I think we were just talking about ways to keep myself occupied - but I don't want to be purely self-involved. I want the world to be better.
The library?
Tak. Make it a forum for discussion and a repository of... well, of culture. For all of us. If we each share some of our local stories and work together to protect them, our heritage can live on.
That's a great idea. It really is.
And I hope it's just the start. I was wondering, do you think you might help me with some of these plans?

Fields.MenuText: Of course I'll help. What good is a captain who lets the ship do all the good works?
Honestly, I'd be a little bit hurt if I wasn't part of your plans going forward. You're certainly part of mine.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Kapitan. It may not be a path of glory, but still one that will leave an important mark in history.
Thank you! You have helped me so much, Kapitan, and... well, I hope to be able to repay your assistance someday.
Oh, I know. For a while it seemed like just being the most dutiful I could be was the real answer... but now I think I have to show some initiative, too.
If this is an extremely polite way of saying you're about to mutiny...
Ha!
For a start, with your permission, I thought I might build upon our library.
Ah. We're back to plans.
Tak. With me, it *always* comes back to plans. You should know that by now.
I wasn't complaining.
